Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 06:55AM itsjustme10 wrote: Since the 2 opinions are so different, I would get a 3rd opinion as a tie-braker. BI-RADS, while the categories are standard,  is a subjective thing, based on the skill and preferences of the radiologist.  It's not some black and white outcome - it's basically a doctor to doctor shorthand on how likely your mass is to be cancerous, based on what he is seeing in the films.  It's not an infallible crystal ball.  No two radiologists are the same - there's a difference in skill level, in experience level, somre are more aggressive in ratings, tending to be higher, than others, etc.  The easy things, everyone gets right and rates the same.  When something isn't textbook, that's where the skill and experience level, as well as personal preferences, come into play.  There have been women on here who had a malignancy, despite a "3" rating, and women who have had benign findings with a "5".  In general, the doctors are fairly accurate, but they're still trying to interpret films.  It's not a sure thing. That's why if it were me, I would get a 3rd opinion - and bring both sets of films with you so they can compare.  :) Good luck!!

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2012 04:00PM - edited Aug 8, 2012 04:19PM by itsjustme10 Hi there!!  I'm sure you don't have IBC, but my recommendation to you is to tell your mom about your concerns, and if she becomes worried, I"m sure she will take you to your doctor.  Summer vacation is really not the time to be spending googling things like IBC... IBC is extremely rare to begin with.  Combine that with how unbelievably rare teenage breast cancer is, and you can see how unlikely that is. It could be anything - you are still developing, so you could be developing at different speeds on each side.  It could be your mom changed laundry detergent or fabric softener, and you're reacting to that.  It could be nothing at all or something completely normal - too much time in a soggy bathing suit caused irritation, you may need a new bra, stuff that's happened before, you just never really noticed it.  Some kind of cream could make it go away, or you might need nothing at all.  No one can really tell you over the internet - and if they say they can, run away!!!  Seriously, what I would tell my 15 year old niece would be to tell her mother.  If you can't find the words, email her this thread, tell her it's you that wrote this, and ask her to take you to the doctor.  But what ever you do, don't obsess over it - just have a professional look at it. I'm sure there's an explanation for everything you're seeing and feeling. Good luck!! :)

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2012 02:25PM itsjustme10 wrote: From what I understand, they don't give you a stage until after your surgery.  That's because if you look at the "staging" info on the website, it's based on technical stats that they won't have until they remove it.  Tests and pictures can tell a lot, but not as much as actually removing the mass and measuring it, and looking at your nodes under a microscope.   It's probably not going to change your treatment all that much, anyway. Calcifications, I hope Beesie comes along to explain, but I think that they're kind of an indicator, not the bad thing.  The cancer is in the tissue, that's why they put the needle where they did.  Calcifications can't hurt you - it's what they represent may be happening in the tissue that causes doctors to want biopsies,.  I hope you understood what I was trying to explain - technical medical information is not my strong point, but I don't want you to be concerned about what was or wasn't tested right now.  The feeling of the lump having doubled in size, could it be some swelling and/or bruising from the biopsy?  They did cut small pieces of tissue out, which does cause trauma.  Breat cancer doesn't usually grow that quickly at all, but if you're concerned, maybe call your doctor and ask. If you love your plastic surgeon back home, use his help to find a surgeon to do the mastectomies.  And if you're not comfortable with the personality of whatever breast surgeon you select, keep looking.  Trust is as important as anything in this journey.  As with any medical problem, it's 90% of the battle.  There are many top notch surgeons out there.  If you believe in them (especially since the pathology is tested afterwards to make sure they got clean margins), then it'll be OK.  it's the plastics guy whose work you're going to look at every day, you know?  And, like I said, he's probably seen how many breast surgeons work...that's your best resource for a referral.  He knows you, he cares about you, etc. I think it's a smart idea to get things done at home.  And I want to compliment you on how well you are handling this situation.  There are women on here that are 2 and 3 times your age that could take a lesson from you.  Best of luck, and please keep us updated!! :)

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2013 09:23PM itsjustme10 wrote: Divorce is one of the qualifying events that make you eligible for COBRA from your ex's employer.  Make sure your attorney puts in a stipulation that he needs to make sure that his HR department sents you the appropriate paperwork.  Because your qualifying event is a divorce or legal separation, your COBRA eligiblity is 36 months.   Obamacare, with guaranteed acceptance kicks in on 1/1/14, so you will have no problem with health insurance. Make sure your attorney stipulates that he must carry the children on his health insurance plan!! After 10 years of marriage, and because you are/were a stay-at-home mom (and I'm assuming your children are his), a halfway decent attorney should be able to get you at least temporary maintenance   I have no idea whether you have enough quarters of work to qualify for SSDI, but it doesn't sound like it. Do not think you can do this alone..everyone starts off with the best of intentions, but it doesn't usually turn out that way.  See the best family divorce attorney you can afford.  Equitable distribution doesn't calculate itself...protect your rights.  The judge will look at what is in the best interest of the children.  A big plus on your side is that you've been a stay-at-home mom for all their lives.  Because of your health, it's so important for them to maintain a strong relationship with their father, no matter how you feel about him.  A judge has to take your health into account, as it would be part of the "best interest" analysis.  But, it shouldn't be anywhere close to the deciding factor. Good luck!!

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2013 02:29PM itsjustme10 wrote: Sugar craving always means PMS to me, not breast cancer.  Salt as well.  Mmmmm....peanut butter cups... No one can tell you from reading whether you have a problem or not.  The radiologist can't even tell you without a biopsy, and he/she went to medical school, and has practiced for years to become board certified.  The pathologist will look at your tissue under a microscope and make a determination.  That's the only definitive way to be sure if something is cancer or not.   Melissa is right - 80% of BIRADS 4 biopsies are negative.  BIRADS 4 ranges from a guesstimate of between 2 and 94% that it's malignant.  In other words, as a categoy, it's basically saying "I don't know" - they see something in there that they can't identify as definitely being benign, nor can they identify it as definitely being malignant.  They'll send you for a biopsy and you'll know for sure.  Until then, there's nothing you can do, no way to guess.  But, the odds are in your favor. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2013 02:34PM itsjustme10 wrote: They can't stage you until after surgery.  They probably could give you a preliminary type and grade from the biopsy sample, but it doesn't matter - it's all coming out, and the surgical pathology is more thorough because the have the whole mass to check.  Staging involves size plus involvement of the nodes, so until the remove the mass, they really can only estimate the size based on imaging, and they really won't know about your nodes until they're removed and checked as well. I don't know your doctor, but that's a good hospital, so I'm sure he's good as well.  Good luck!! :)

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 07:56AM itsjustme10 wrote: You say that 5 years ago your chest X-Ray showed a pleural adhesion?  Honestly, and to be quite frank, don't you think that without treatment for 5 years of lung metastesis, you might not be typing this to us right now? As a nurse, you know that not only is nothing cancer until a biopsy says it's cancer, but also that breast cancer is treatable.  I get that you're scared.  I understand that you don't want to upset your family.  But, think about this carefully before you answer...which would upset them more?  Helping you get through treatment, or finding out you ignored it, having it be bad, and not find out you have breast cancer until it's too late to help you? So, either go for the physical and let the findings be a "surprise" to everyone, or admit you have *something* going on to your family, and get yourself checked.  You are educated enough to understand ithat ultimately it's the best way to go.  Fear of the unknown is understandable, but ignoring it won't make it go away. Hopefully it's nothing - and you, as a nurse, know that the vast majority of breast issues end up being benign conditions.  You, as a nurse, also know that you cannot self-diagnose cancer, as there are many things that could be causing your symptoms.  So, go get your tests and find out whether you need to worry or not. Good luck!!

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 12:21PM itsjustme10 wrote: Hi Dale, Congratulations on the baby - that's certainly an awesome thing for you both to look forward to.  Chemo is do-able - just take all the anti-nausea drugs she's alllowed, and drink a LOT.  Eat what your body says to eat, not what your head says.  I craved carbs - I know they're not the best for you, but I went with that, and it was fine.  The hair part sucks.  I won't lie - that's the part I personally freaked the most over.  If I may make a suggestion - iether you or her hairdresser might want to give her a buzz cut right around the time of her 2nd treatment - that's when it starts falling out by the handful, and it's easier if she loses it on her own terms.  Mine started coming out on my way to the supermarket, so I ended up buying a baseball cap there, 'cause I was afraid I'd have a bald spot by the time I got home (I didn't, but I did get it shaved that day). Besides the wigs, there's a website called "hatswithhair.com".  I lived in the ponymode style - I had my hair dresser cut the bangs and length a bit, and she curled the front, and I wore it more often than the wig - it was a lot more comfortable, and breathed more than the wigs, and I could put it on in 2 seconds. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2012 12:08PM itsjustme10 wrote: When you go to specialists, they well, specialize, I guess..  I know where I had chemo, they asked if I wanted to talk to someone, the social worker came over, gave me her card, said if I wanted to talk, call any time, even after treatment ended, that they were there for us.  That was nice of her.  It seemed like the nurses during chemo were the ones who talked the most with patients - but then again, we were a captive audience, and they were limited in their work by the number of chairs, so they had time. Your surgeon is there for 1 reason - surgery.  The MO is there to make sure your chemo is going smoothly, then to follow up at regular intervals.  Your RO makes sure you do well with radiation. If any doctor should've been the coordinator, it probably should've been your PCP.  That's the general who dictates the rest, who treats the whole person, as much as any doctor does these days.  When HMO's pay by capitation or a teeny amount per visit, when PPO's pay a fraction of what's billed, when Medicare caps reimbursements, it's no wonder that doctors don't have time for anything like that - they need to see enough patients to be able to pay for their malpractice insurance, office rent and staff.  If you know you want to be referred to a support group, why not ask the office staff to give you a list?  I've found that no matter what the situation, if you ask for things, people are very nice, and tend to go out of the way to help you get them.  Be proactive!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 08:33AM itsjustme10 wrote: Even if a tech thought he or she spotted a mass, a tech is not a doctor, and until a radiologist reads the films, whatever some tech thought they saw is not a finding.  It could've been something that had been there for years, and the doctors were watching, but the tech wouldn't have known.  So, it had to wait until the radiologist could examine your current films and compare them to prior films. As to why they didn't order more testing that day, there could be many valid reasons...only a doctor can read your films and make a determination if further testing is needed.  Even if that happened right away, if the radiology group was booked, you would have to make an appointment for further testing no matter what.  Plus, depending on your insurance plan, you may need additional approvals, and that could easily take a day or more to obtain. As for your doctor's receptionist, no comment on her comments on thinking she can run another doctor's practice.... Depending on what permissions you granted the radiology group on your HIPAA forms, they may or may not have beeen allowed to have told you anything over the phone. Did you request a copy of the films when you were there, and to have a report mailed to you?  You are most definitely allowed to do that, and should - always get copies of your tests for your own records.  That way, these things can't happen to you.  It is frustrating, but part of how things work, so you have to learn to work around the system, 'cause you can't fight it.  Make sure you get a copy of the US or whatever you're having done Monday - they give you a CD - and ask them to mail you a copy of the report when it's ready.  They'll be happy to do that.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 10:16PM itsjustme10 wrote: Hi Emily, I'm sorry you're going through all of this.  I'm sure that in your research that you've seen just how rare it would be for someone your age to be diagnosed with breast cancer.  IBC, despite its appearing so often in searches, is a very rare form of breast cancer.  If you combine the odds of it being IBC with your age, it's really really really unlikely.  That being said, stay off Google!!!  It's a decent search engine, but a terrible diagnostician. It sounds like your mom is on top of everything, and since the only advice I would feel comfortable giving you would be to tell your mom, you have done the 100% correct thing.  It also sounds like your mom is not taking "no" for an answer, but is willing to push to make sure you get answers that she is comfortable with.  There is nothing more you can do,  except wait, and keep your mom updated on how your symptoms are resolving, or any new ones that you get - exactly what you are doing.  I'm not sure where you read that the redness from IBC would come and go, but it sounds intuitively wrong - cancer can't be cured by antibiotics, it doesn't respond to creams, and it doesn't go away on it's own.  That's another problem with the internet  - it's hard to tell what is true or not - there is a difference between reading medical journals and reading personal stories, when you don't know who the author is, and whether what their saying is true or not, or accurate or not. Emily, you're 14.  Don't try to out-think your doctors. You can't.  Medical school is an additional 4 years after college - that's a lot of education that your doctors went through.  Of course you feel lost, and I'm sure you are worried - talk to your mom about it - from what you say, she really understands and cares.  That's who you should be getting your information from, not a bunch of people on the web. Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 01:03PM itsjustme10 wrote: The short answer is that no one knows for sure whether something is malignant or not without the pathology results from the biopsy.  It is true that 80% of biopsies come back benign.  Hopefully yours will too, because something can "look" bad, but be OK under the microscope. The Birad scale is a subjective rating system, and is wholly dependent on the skill of the radiologist reading your films, and how he interprets what he sees, so don't get too hung up on that.  And it makes sense that it would be rated Birads 5, based on what your radiologist told you.  Radiologists are board certified specialists.  They do have a lot of training, and know what they are looking at.  And apparently what he sees caught his attention. There is always a chance that his opinion was incorrect, because all it is is an educated guess.  You won't know until you get your biopsy results back.  I hope for your sake that he was not right.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 02:27AM itsjustme10 wrote: Smethot...If you choose reconstruction, and have to have radiation, the 2 years is pretty close... I had to wait months after finishing radiation to have my exchange surgery, which is what made it so long - I would say about 18 months or so from finding the mass to the exchange.  The 9 months between finishing radiation and having the exchnage was kind of a waiting period, more than anything, though - more annoying that the time wouldn't go faster.  The stupid TE's were a constant reminder, only because they weren't exactly the most comfortable things ever.  I chose implants for reconstruction, so once my exchange was done, I was almost completely healed.  People who choose more invasive procedures have different healing times, and it probably would push you closer to the 2 years. Your hair starts growing back right after your final chemo treatment.  I'm 16 months from finishing chemo, and my hair is past my shoulders - it's still a little too short to be comfortable wearing it up in a pony tail, but I look like me again - that's probably been  2 months since I've been comfortable with how the front looks, so that would be 14 months after chemo.  Of course, if you have short hair, your feelings on the matter would be much different.  I wore my wig for like 8 months after finishing chemo- I was not walking out looking like THAT, but there are people who are comfortable with really short hair and ditch the wig as soon as they have any coverage.  It's a personal choice, but it does grow back right away - it just takes time to grow enough for you to be OK with how you look.  That amount of time varies, as it's very personal to each of us. As for how long until you stop thinking about it, that's a personality thing, so it's really up to you.  Good luck!!  And, seriously, you will look back one day and realize how far you've come.

Posts.Content: May 30, 2012 10:03PM itsjustme10 wrote: Lumut, I know you're really concerned, but before you take any advice on the internet, please listen for a second. Your mother has a bunch of chronic illnesses, and I"m going to guess that she's being properly treated for all of them.  That means she's taking certain medications.  Some of those medicines may require staying away or limiting certain foods. Do you know if your mother is on blood thinners - something called Coumadin or Warfarin?  If she is, be very very careful before recommending that she eat greens - the Vitamin K in green leafy vegetables, like spinach, broccoli, cauliflower, etc. - all those that are good for fighting cancer - that works to cancel out the theraputic effects of the blood thinner.  There are certain foods you need to stay away from with gout.  Certain foods you need to stay away from with diabetes. Low sodium is important to remember with high blood pressure.  Try and make an appointment for yourself and your mother with a nutritionist in her cancer center - they would be able to create a diet, including portion sizes and recommend supplements, that would take all of her medical conditions and medications into account.  They know the side effects of her medications, and can cross-check that as against any food or vitamins.  Your mom's case is a bit complicated, but I'm sure her medical team has seen that plus more a thousand times over.  Don't try to guess on herbal supplements on your own - you're not taking her prescriptions medications into account.  Let the professionals do it.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 06:20PM itsjustme10 wrote: That seems like a long time, but if you were on Tamoxifen, which is supposed to not let hormone positive breast cancer thrive, hopefully you're OK.  I have to admit, I haven't seen a situation on here like this - that doesn't mean it doesn't exist, but usually re-excisions are done pretty quickly.   Your plastic surgeon was OK with doing an exchange, even though you didn't have clean margins for about 6 months at that time?  There's no way to know what it's done - there are many people who go back for 2 or 3 excisions, without a wait, because of close or dirty margins. Many of those women end up having mastectomies because their surgeons can't get clean margins.   As for malpractice and/or negligence, probably not- you were told the margins were not clean, and it was up to you to be proactive in following up.  If your surgeon didn't call you immediately to schedule it, you certainly could have called him or her.  Hopefully the tamoxifen did its job and killed the cancer cells that remained behind.  They were always there - that's what not having clean margins mean, so whether it's grown more or not, you won't know until after your surgery.  The other thing is, you don't know whether you would've had clean margins after an immediate re-excision, either.  As a matter of fact, while not the optimal situation, having such a late re-excision will let you know whether the tamoxifen is effective in your body or not. Good luck!!   Hope you get good results. :)

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2012 11:38AM itsjustme10 wrote: I wouldn't want to see the nurse...keep calling to see if there are cancellations, but you deserve to see the actual doctor.  One is not a substitute for the other... Doctors go through medical school, internships, residencies, board certification, etc.  One thing you will find out is what I have learned  -  that *my* defninition of immediate and doctors' definitions of immediate are two different things.  Hurry up and wait is the best way to describe it - everything is a week, 2 weeks, a month.  Supposedly breast cancer is usually quite slow-growing, so nothing needs to be done that second. You have a surgeon's appointment.  Call them every few days to see if there was a cancellation.  Tell them you're flexible, and you can come in immediately if necessary.  But, don't short-change yourself by settling for less than a board certified physician. Surgeons may have different ways of wording requests for tests than PCP's do.  It's not necessarily a question of having "pull" with an insurance company - although I have no doubt that some high powered doctors do - it's more of a question of knowing what specific words to use to get that elusive approval.  So, if your surgeon feels you need an MRI, they will find a way to word the request, so that it is approved as medically necessary. Good luck - I know waiting sucks, but unfortunately, it's the game we all play. :(

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2013 08:59PM itsjustme10 wrote: Do you live in an area impacted by the snow? Is the pathology lab in an area impacted by the snow?  I know a lot of businesses closed early on Friday, for the safety of their employees.  Even if they weren't impacted, it's really only been 4 business days - I know it feels longer, but Saturday and Sunday don't count. Plus you don't know whether it was sent out Wednesday night or Thursday morning.  And, there's no way to determine what, if any, delay the storm caused.  Waiting sucks.  I'm sorry you're going through this, but it's better that they take the time they need to get it right, and not rush something through and make an error.  I'm sure it will be available soon.  Why not call from your cell phone after work, and see if you can stop by on your way home tomorrow?  Or, if you call from the office, just ask if your test results are in - that doesn't give anything away. :)

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2012 02:15PM itsjustme10 wrote: Since your cancer is already in your lymph nodes, they want the scan to see if it's anywhere else in your body, as that would change your treatment.  I was also stage IIb, but that was because of the size of my ILC, my nodes were clear, so I didn't have to have a CT scan or bone scan.  I can tell you that if any of my nodes were positive, and they wanted additional scans, I would have complied - they need to know what's going on, and what, exactly they're treating.  They did give me a PET scan, which was also clear, and while I wasn't happy being radioactive for a day, it seemed like a small price to pay for peace of mind. I guess you have to balance your concerns about radiation with the doctor's concerns of whether your cancer may or may not have spread, because of his/her concerns over your positive nodes.  My suggestion would be to discuss the pros and cons of this diagnostic tool with your doctor.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2013 09:50AM - edited Feb 11, 2013 09:51AM by itsjustme10 Hi!!  You might want to get copies of the reports from your mammo, ultrasound and biopsy, not necessarily to read, but just to have - it's always good in case you change doctors or move or something - the films are usually in CD form, and the report is usually short.  Some people are really organized - not me - mine are in a bag in the back of my closet somewhere.  But I do have them!!  And when they remove this lump from you, try to remember to ask them to mail you a copy of the pathology report from that surgery for your records, too. :) There are a bunch of abnormal non-cancerous things it could've been - since I didn't have any of them, I don't remember the names, but basically, better out than in is a good way to look at it.  It's great that once you have it removed, you're done...

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2012 11:17AM - edited Dec 3, 2012 11:17AM by itsjustme10 I'm sorry you were just diagnosed, and have to go through this.  I'm sure someone witlh more information will be along to help you more.  I believe, from reading other posts, and NOT because I am a doctor, so I aplogize if I'm forwarding incorrect information, but "axillary" nodes ARE your lymph nodes, but it's identified that way to indicate the location.  So they are answering you when you ask whether your lymph nodes are involved- they think it is in your nodes - in those that they mentioned...but that's just from screening tests, and they won't know for total sure until they do surgery and remove them and check them. It'll be easier once you get all the diagnostics behind you, and a treatment & surgical plan in place.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2012 07:15PM - edited Nov 25, 2012 07:24PM by itsjustme10 The waiting is the worst part, I know. :(  Hang in there...it's just a little more than a week away. I wish there was a magic formula and someone could tell you "yes" or "no", but there isn't.  Even experienced board certified radiologists sometimes  interpret what they see differently.  That's why the gold standard is a biopsy.  Believe me, you don't want somone's uneducated guess that they word as a definitive opinion.  The truth is that no one could possibly know for sure until it's biopsied.  If your doctor were comfortable (either way) he probably would've given you a hint.  Waiting sucks.  But someone on some message board guessing wrong based solely on their own personal results, and not actual knowledge, and then acting like they kinow what they're talking about and telling you something that isn't true, would suck even more.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 06:43PM - edited Feb 16, 2013 06:46PM by itsjustme10 ymrd... if I were in your shoes, I think that I would be checking all the local Philly places for their opinions..from what I remember reading, other than hormone therapy, like tamoxifen, your choices will probably be either lumpectomy & radiation, or mastectomy.  Either way, while the thought of Georgia weather in the middle of the winter is really enticing, radiation is given 5 days/week for 5 or 6 weeks!!  Are you in a position to be able to be away from home for 5 days/week if that's the route you choose? Or, should you make the other choice, would you be comfortable travelling for surgery?   I think I've read that CTCA arranges for your travel & lodging (not sure who pays, though), if that makes a difference. That's a choice that only you can make, though... This is the hardest part, right now - the learning, the researching, the driving yourself nuts - once you get a treatment plan in place, things calm down, and you can take it 1 step at a time. :) Oh, and..if you really want to travel for other opinions, why not consider visiting either MD Anderson in Texas, or Memorial Sloan Kettering in NYC - they're rated 1 and 2 in cancer care in the world. :)

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 07:03PM itsjustme10 wrote: I agree - get another opinion -surgeon, plastic surgeon, wound care, breast specialist, even a dermatologist, any or all of them... especially if you think you want another biopsy. I don't care how big your breasts are - think about it - really heavy people have surgery all the time, without this kind of complication.  Girls have implants put in, their breasts become bigger than yours, and their scars aren't pulled open.  What I would tell a friend is  - get another opinion, but make sure they are in no way related to either of your 2 original surgeons.  No partners, no referrals, etc.  Someone is missing something - it shouldn't be doing that. Please keep us updated. :)

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 03:16PM itsjustme10 wrote: You are more than entitled to get a 2nd or even 3rd opinion, and if that involves changing hospitals, so be it.  I can't imagine using a surgeon I didn't have 110% trust in, so go for it!! :) I will tell you that prior to my BMX, my plastic surgeon (who has staff privileges in at least 4 hospitals that I know of off hand) told me not to get too hung up on which hospital I had it done at - he literally said it wasn't brain surgery - LOL - and that for a BMX or lumpectomy, as long as you trusted the doctor, the hospital itself was just a facility.  He said if I were having heart or brain surgery, he would give me a different answer.  Now, whether he said this to calm my nerves,or whether he really meant it, I can't answer, but it did take the pressure off me, and enabled me to handle some other things at the same time as the BMX, while using the same BS and PS. If you haven't had chemo prior to surgery, I would suggest contacting MSK prior to agreeing to do anything, because that's where they would be at the forefront of any newer protocols.  As for surgery, it's the skill of the breast surgeon, (and plastic surgeon, if necessary) that you need to believe in.  Which hospitals does your current breast surgeon have privileges at? Good luck - I know it's a huge choice, and not easy...

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2012 04:19AM itsjustme10 wrote: What did your doctors say?  Do they want you to have an immediate  biopsy, or are they just going to recheck it at a later date?  It stinks to be going through something, but what are you concerned about?  Waiting for a biopsy and test results, or the microcalcifications themselves?    What does your written report say about them?  Does your radiology group find them suspicious?  The only advice I can or would give you is that Google is not the best way to self-diagnose things.  If you're having a biopsy, wait until the results come in, and then you can start researching.  Otherwise, you're just making yourself nervous for no reason.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2012 09:20AM - edited Nov 22, 2012 09:22AM by itsjustme10 I think her age and general overall healty are things to take into consideration when trying to figure out what she'll need in terms of help...   I can tell you that I came home from a BMX with TE's put in, stayed 2 nights in the hospital, and the day after coming home, I was cooking for and taking care of my mom.  Reaching was a little hard but I fought through the pulling sensation, and each day saw progress as to how high I could reach.  Of course, that's why I drained so much, and it took longer to get the drains pulled because of how active I was.  Her surgeon may even give her some exercises to do.  Mine showed me one, but I had no range of motion problems, so I was kind of lax about doing it. My biggest problem was getting in and out of bed, which I solved by first renting a recliner, then within that first month, since it was so comfortable, buying a LazyBoy recliner with a power button.  The pain killers made me sleepy - which I hated - so I kind of lived in the recliner all day and night for a short time.  Driving was kind of hard - well, the backing out of the driveway part was the worst, because turning around to see was hard.  After a short while, I alternated pain killers with Advil - and had completely stopped them, except for at night within a week or two of getting home.  The 4 drains bothered me - caused most of my discomfort - they cut nerves when they do a bmx, so your chest area is numb anyway.    Considering how big the surgery seems, when you think about it, it isn't all that terrible to recover from physically.

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 08:51AM itsjustme10 wrote: My friend's grandmother had the same thing happen.  She was in her late 90's, failing both physically and mentally at that time, and they found a lump when she was hospitalized.  In her case, they wanted to biopsy and all that.  My friend's mother looked at them and said "tell me exactly how that will improve the length or quality of her life".  Crickets...  If your mother could communicate, what do you think she would want to do?  Do you think she's happy being how she is now, and knowing it's only going to progress?  Do you think she would want physically and mentally debilitating treatments for what would probably be little or no additional quality time on earth?  Listen to the doctor, don't torture yourself.  It's the humane thing to do.
